citations.narrative:
The disposition information was not documented for 1 blackbuck and 2 muntjac that, per a facility representative, were
transferred to other institutions during this past year. Without records which fully disclose the animal’s disposition, legal
and medical information traceback is not possible. Maintain records disclosing the required acquisition/disposition
information including the date, name, address, and USDA number if applicable of the person from whom the animal was
acquired from or transferred to. Correct by August 26, 2025.

On three consecutive days, January 1st, 2nd and 3rd of 2025, a bobcat entered the muntjac enclosures and killed a total
of 3 muntjacs. Per a facility representative, the bobcat climbed the fencing to enter the enclosures. The enclosures were
not constructed in a manner to prevent predator entrance and thus did not safely contain the animals.
At the time of inspection, the following areas in need of repair were identified:
- Many trees were seen growing over the metal fence nearest the road of the blackbuck enclosure. That stretch of fencing
was leaning a great deal into the enclosure.
- Two large limbs had broken from a tree and were laying on top of fences within the muntjac enclosures. The fence
closest to the entrance gate as well as the furthest one denoting the enclosures’ end, were shortened and leaning under
the weight of the tree limbs.
- The wooden door into the second muntjac enclosure was leaning into the animal’s space. The base of the wooden poles
making up the door frame had a brown/dark green color and appeared to be rotting with some fraying/gaps in the wood.
Areas in disrepair such as these may affect structural integrity thus diminishing the enclosures’ ability to safely contain the
animals.
The facility must be constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate for the animals involved. Housing
facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to safely
contain them. Correct by October 13, 2025.

During inspection, the open bag of pelleted feed that was currently in use was not being stored adequately. The feed bag
was being kept within a wooden shed amongst a crowded accumulation of trash, and other bagged items. Old
disintegrated feed pellets containing a large number of bugs could be seen on the floor of the shed beneath the feed bag.
Unsanitary food storage conditions may lead to food contamination/deterioration, may attract vermin and could lead to the
spread of disease. Supplies of food and bedding shall be stored in facilities which adequately protect such supplies
against deterioration, molding, or contamination by vermin. Correct by August 19, 2025.

All the water receptacles in both muntjac enclosures (one enclosure with 5 muntjac while the other had 3) were in need of
cleaning. The five containers had a thick layer of slimy green fuzzy material coating the bottom. A moderate amount of
larvae could be seen moving within the water of two bowls. Dirty water receptacles may contaminate the water contained
within which may negatively impact animal health and comfort. Clean potable water is necessary for the health and
comfort of the animals. All water receptacles must be kept clean and sanitary. Correct by August 14, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
KRISTIN NAPOLI, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALIST n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The disposition information was not documented for 1 blackbuck and 2 muntjac that, per a facility representative, were 
transferred to other institutions during this past year. Without records which fully disclose the animal’s disposition, legal 
and medical information traceback is not possible. Maintain records disclosing the required acquisition/disposition 
information including the date, name, address, and USDA number if applicable of the person from whom the animal was 
acquired from or transferred to. Correct by August 26, 2025. 
3.125(a)  Critical
   
Facilities, general. 
On three consecutive days, January 1st, 2nd and 3rd of 2025, a bobcat entered the muntjac enclosures and killed a total 
of 3 muntjacs. Per a facility representative, the bobcat climbed the fencing to enter the enclosures. The enclosures were 
not constructed in a manner to prevent predator entrance and thus did not safely contain the animals. 
 
At the time of inspection, the following areas in need of repair were identified: 
- Many trees were seen growing over the metal fence nearest the road of the blackbuck enclosure. That stretch of fencing 
was leaning a great deal into the enclosure.  
- Two large limbs had broken from a tree and were laying on top of fences within the muntjac enclosures. The fence 
closest to the entrance gate as well as the furthest one denoting the enclosures’ end, were shortened and leaning under 
the weight of the tree limbs.  
- The wooden door into the second muntjac enclosure was leaning into the animal’s space. The base of the wooden poles 
making up the door frame had a brown/dark green color and appeared to be rotting with some fraying/gaps in the wood.  
Areas in disrepair such as these may affect structural integrity thus diminishing the enclosures’ ability to safely contain the 
animals. 
 
The facility must be constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate for the animals involved. Housing 
facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to safely 
contain them. Correct by October 13, 2025. 
3.125(c)

Facilities, general. 
During inspection, the open bag of pelleted feed that was currently in use was not being stored adequately. The feed bag 
was being kept within a wooden shed amongst a crowded accumulation of trash, and other bagged items. Old 
disintegrated feed pellets containing a large number of bugs could be seen on the floor of the shed beneath the feed bag. 
Unsanitary food storage conditions may lead to food contamination/deterioration, may attract vermin and could lead to the 
spread of disease. Supplies of food and bedding shall be stored in facilities which adequately protect such supplies 
against deterioration, molding, or contamination by vermin. Correct by August 19, 2025. 
3.130 
   
Watering. 
All the water receptacles in both muntjac enclosures (one enclosure with 5 muntjac while the other had 3) were in need of 
cleaning. The five containers had a thick layer of slimy green fuzzy material coating the bottom. A moderate amount of 
larvae could be seen moving within the water of two bowls. Dirty water receptacles may contaminate the water contained 
within which may negatively impact animal health and comfort. Clean potable water is necessary for the health and 
comfort of the animals. All water receptacles must be kept clean and sanitary. Correct by August 14, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
KRISTIN NAPOLI, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALIST n
